description: The function 'draw_box_plots' generates box plots, a type of graphical representation that provides a visual interpretation of numerical data through their quartiles. It is an effective tool for teaching statistical concepts such as median, quartiles, and outliers. The function can generate single or multiple box plots with custom colors, making it easier for learners to differentiate and compare data sets.

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Box Plots
stimulus_type_specification.description: The 'draw_box_plots' function creates box plots, which are graphical representations of numerical data through their quartiles. The function accepts input of type 'BoxPlotData', which includes minimum value, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum value of a data set. It can generate single or multiple box plots, each with a unique color for better differentiation. The function validates that each successive value in the 'BoxPlotData' is larger than the previous one, ensuring the data is correctly ordered for a box plot. This function serves an educational purpose by aiding in the teaching and understanding of statistical concepts.

details: class_name: Name of the class or category for the data set. It is optional for single box plots and required for multiple box plots.
min_value: The minimum value in the data set.
q1: The first quartile value in the data set.
median: The median value in the data set.
q3: The third quartile value in the data set.
max_value: The maximum value in the data set.
title: Title of the box plot. It is optional for single box plots and required for multiple box plots.
The function validates that each successive value in the 'BoxPlotData' is larger than the previous one.
For multiple box plots, a title and class name for each data set are required.
For single box plots, class name should not be provided.
The function generates box plots, with each box plot representing a data set.
Each box plot is colored uniquely for easy differentiation.
The position, size, and color of the box plots are determined by the input parameters.

educational_standards.display_name: Interpret Measures of Center and Variability
educational_standards.description: Interpret given statistical summaries—mean/median (measures of center) and range/IQR/MAD (measures of variability)—to describe what is typical and how much values vary in real-world contexts.
Display numerical data on box plots.

Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.

educational_standards.display_name: Using Random Samples to Compare Populations
educational_standards.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
